_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sierra Chemical Company a Carus Group Inc. company, is a leader in the water purification chemical industry manufactures and distributes environmental chemicals for the municipal, agricultural, mining, and industrial markets. Sierra Chemical Company and the Carus Group support American Chemistry Council's Responsible Distribution, an initiative that fosters involvement in the community and continuous improvement in environmental, health, security, and safety performance.  Sierra Chemical Company is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors and has been certified to be in compliance with the Responsible Distribution Code. The company is also an active member of the Chlorine Institute, a trade group that develops and establishes recommended practices for the safe handling of chlorine.



The Sierra Chemical Company, Stockton, CA plant is a chemical manufacturer, packager and distributor of industrial chemicals. The markets for the Stockton plant include water treatment, wastewater treatment, industrial applications, agriculture, and food processing. Chlorine is packaged and distributed for the water treatment, wastewater treatment, agriculture and industrial markets. Sulfur dioxide is distributed through the Stockton facility from our Sparks, NV packaging facility for water treatment, wastewater treatment, and industrial markets. Carus Corporation states in its EHSS Charter that the Environmental, Health, Safety, and Security Mission  is to achieve a manufacturing environment that we are proud of  by continuously improving our ability to provide  our customers  with quality products and services that meet their needs while operating with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance. To operate with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance our commitment to EHSS must include: compliance with work instructions and procedures; clear expectations; a constant focus on prevention; active participation; awareness on and

off the job; strong leadership; and personal responsibility.  Further, a commitment to EHSS must include personal accountability for their EHSS performance and for the EHSS performance of those they manage or supervise.  A commitment on the part of all employees and contractors is crucial to achieving the EHSS mission. Compliance with all expectations set forth in the EHSS Charter will help develop the EHSS culture and ensure Carus operates with the highest standards of safety and environmental awareness. These expectations are a key part of job performance assessments. Carus will not tolerate failure to live up to the expectations outlined in this charter; as such failure could negatively impact the health and safety of our employees, our community, and the environment.  The EHSS Charter has been reviewed and endorsed by Sierra Chemical Company, Stockton Plant personnel and plant management demonstrates EHSS leadership and commitment.



In addition to EPA's RMP rule, the Stockton plant complies with State and Federal OSHA's Process Safety Management, EPA's State and Federal Hazardous Waste Generator, DHS Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard and DOT's Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration regulatory requirements.



In this RMP submission, there is one Worst-case toxic release scenario and one Alternative Case toxic release scenario evaluated at the Stockton plant for each of the two toxic gases; chlorine and sulfur dioxide. Section 2 of this RMP submittal contains additional details regarding the Worst-case release scenario while Section 3 contains additional details for the Alternative Case release scenario. 



The Hazard Prediction and Analysis Capability (HPAC) model was developed by the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) through the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA). These HPAC models has been approved by the Chlorine Institute and is published in their Pamphlet 74 Edition 6 and was used to develop the worst-case and alternative scen

arios for all chlorine releases and to determine the greatest distances to the chlorine toxic endpoint of 3 ppm.





For chlorine, the Worst-case toxic release scenario has been determined to be a chlorine 90-ton rail car releasing 180,000 pounds with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 0.33 mile. The scenario and conditions are described in Chlorine Institute's Pamphlet 74 Edition 6 as:



4.4.4 90-Ton Rail Car



? Total mass release = 180,000 lbs.

? Duration of release = 10 minutes

? Release state = gas

? Release rate:300 lbs./second

? Release occurs on concrete

? Wind Speed = 1.5 m/s @ 3 ppm

? Maximum downwind distance = 1765 ft.

? Maximum width = 2654 ft.





An Alternative Case toxic release scenario to be a 1-inch schedule 80 pipe failure gas-phase release with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 0.24 mile. The scenario and conditions are described in Chlorine Institute's Pamphlet 74 Edition 6 as:



4.4.5 1-Inch Pipe Failure (gas) A 1-inch schedule 80 pipe is sheared off. An infinite supply is assumed, and mitigation is

assumed to occur after one hour.



? Container type: pipe

? Release mechanism: failure

? Release state: gas

? Release rate: 137 lbs./minute

? Contents mass: 8,208 lbs.

? Duration of release: 60 minutes

? Hole elevation: 15 ft.

? Opening diameter: 1 inch

? Wind Speed = 3 m/s @ 3 ppm

? Maximum downwind distance = 1273 ft.

? Maximum width = 807 ft.





For sulfur dioxide, the Worst-case toxic release scenario has been determined to be a sulfur dioxide tonner cylinder releasing 2,000 pounds with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 1.0 mile and an Alternative Case toxic release scenario to be a 150 pound sulfur dioxide cylinder  with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 0.20 mile. EPA's Cameo (Aloha, Marplot, cameo chemical) model and RMP*Comp were used to determine the greatest distances to the sulfur dioxide toxic endpoint of 3 ppm.



To ensure a common basis for comparisons, EPA defined the wors

t-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line that results in the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint, in these cases were 0.33 mile for chlorine and 1.0 mile for sulfur dioxide. The alternative release scenario is a release that is considered more reasonable or "more likely." These maximum distances are used to determine the radii for circles around the covered processes.



Residential populations within these circles are required to be determined based on available census information; hence, the population number for each scenario is reported as part of this RMP submittal. These estimates were acquired from the EPA Marplot software.  Since wind direction cannot be anticipated for an accidental release, EPA mandated the circle estimation method. This method greatly over estimates the population potentially exposed to an individual release since the prominent wind direction and other factors are not taken into account. Generally, the Stockton Plant components for the accidental release prevention program includes a commitment to process safety, an understanding of hazards and risk, management of risk and learning from experience as well as compliance with regulatory requirements.  



The plant has a Process Safety Management (PSM) system for the covered processes as defined by OSHA. The chlorine and sulfur dioxide program documentation includes the following PSM elements: process safety information; process hazard analysis; operating procedures; training; mechanical integrity; management of change; pre-startup safety review; compliance audits; incident investigations; employee participation; hot work permit; contractor management; and emergency planning and response. Throughout the plant, a hierarchy of controls has been implemented including hazard elimination, substitution, engineering controls, toxic gas sensors, administrative controls and personal protective equipment to mini

mize or eliminate exposure to hazards.



Infrastructure security improvements at designated areas in the plant have been implemented that provide layers of protection against deliberate man-made incidents in accordance with applicable elements of U.S. Department of Homeland Security's CFATS Risk Based Performance Standards.



In the last five years, the Stockton plant has had one accidental release that resulted in an employee injury; a small chlorine release on April 14, 2014 that resulted in < 1 pound of chlorine gas being emitted into the atmosphere.  An upset situation caused chlorine to be present during the connection procedure and a small puff of chlorine exposed an operator, who was not wearing the proper PPE, to the gas which resulted in an injury requiring time off work.

 

The plant has a trained emergency response team comprised of on-site personnel that meets applicable OSHA and other regulatory requirements. In-plant emergency response team training includes classroom instruction; hands-on demonstrations. Plant emergency response team members attend the Mississippi Fire Academy's HAZMAT Response Training as part of their training program. The response team is also trained to provide support at off-site chlorine emergencies through the Chlorine Institutes CHLOREP Program which is a voluntary aid program for chlorine emergencies occurring during transportation or at user locations. Furthermore, the EHSS Manager is actively involved in emergency planning with community emergency management and response stakeholders including participation on the California Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Board. A plant management team representative attends the Chlorine Institute's Annual and Fall Meetings to learn new safety-related developments and best practices involving the safe production, use and distribution of chlorine, and applies these same best practices to sulfur dioxide when applicable.



Several changes to improve safety and security are plann

ed, budgeted or being implemented including process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection system upgrades, security and physical protection systems, and plant-wide hazard reviews/evaluations.  For example, Sierra Chemical has expanded the Process Engineer position's responsibilities to include PSM/RMP compliance support for the Stockton, California plants in their PSM and RMP activities such as providing audit assistance, process hazard analysis lead/facilitator role, regulatory updates, PSM incident analysis and sharing best practices. Also, this individual provides leadership, safety culture, and policy guidance to Sierra Chemical Company management regarding their PSM/RMP programs.
